newsitem.title: UGANDA: Regional conference reviews Burundi sanctions.
newsitem.headline: Regional conference reviews Burundi sanctions.

text.p: A regional ministerial conference to review sanctions imposed by African leaders on the central African state of Burundi opened in Uganda on Saturday, officials said.

Foreign ministers from Tanzania, Rwanda, Uganda, Kenya, Ethiopia, Zambia and the Democratic Republic of the Congo met in Kampala to assess the effectiveness of sanctions imposed by their governments and decide whether to recommend their lifting.
Regional countries led by Tanzania slapped sanctions on Burundi on July 31 last year after Tutsi military strongman Pierre Buyoya ousted Hutu civilian president Sylvestre Ntibantunganya.
The sanctions were intended to force Buyoya to reinstate constitutional rule and negotiate with Hutu rebels.
The embargo has since been eased to allow in humanitarian food supplies and medicines.

More than 150,000 people have died in Burundi since October 1993, when the country's first freely elected president, Melchior Ndadaye -- a Hutu -- was murdered by Tutsi troops in an failed coup attempt.
The coup attempt was followed by a wave of reprisals by enraged Hutus, widely regarded as "genocide" by Burundi's Tutsi minority, and counter-attacks from the Tutsi-dominated army.
The conference comes nine days ahead of the start of peace talks between Burundi's Tutsi military junta, political parties and Hutu rebels in the northern Tanzanian town of Arusha.
The talks will be chaired by Julius Nyerere, former Tanzanian president and the internationally-backed mediator on Burundi.
But the Burundi government has accused Tanzania of siding with the Hutu rebels fighting Buyoya's government.

Speaking in Nairobi on Friday Burundi's Foreign Minister Luc Rukingama said Tanzania had demonstrated open hostility towards Burundi by giving rebels sanctuary in the former Burundi embassy in Dar es Salaam and by spearheading regional sanctions against Bujumbura.
